intro: Chaenocephalus heterophyllus, commonly known as the variable-headed flax, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, often asymmetrical floral structures. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or stream banks. Its leaves are usually alternate and vary in shape, contributing to its common name. The flowers are typically blue or violet, with a unique, helmet-shaped corolla that aids in pollination by specific insect species.
